Additionally, we examine adaptive massively parallel sort-merge join algorithms for heterogeneous systems, extending these algorithms to support diverse big data environments. Lastly, we explore context-aware AI for urban and environmental management, combining large language models with other AI models for more sophisticated and context-aware decision support systems. Finally, we explore the use of geometric deep learning for graph neural networks, by defining neural network operations on graphs to develop more powerful and expressive models for graph-structured data. Title: Advances and Challenges in Graph Neural Networks: Multi-scale Representations, Robustness, Explainability, and Lifelong Learning

Abstract: Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) have emerged as a powerful tool for learning on graph-structured data, with applications in various fields such as social networks, recommendation systems, and bioinformatics. This paper explores four key areas in GNN research: multi-scale representations, robustness, explainability, and lifelong learning. First, we discuss multi-scale GNNs that effectively capture both local and global graph structures, addressing the need for explicit 3D shape preprocessing and enabling real-world applications like robotics and augmented reality. Second, we investigate integrating GNNs with differentiable renderers, which can enable learning 3D shape representations directly from raw 2D image data. Third, we study adversarial training techniques for GNNs to enhance their robustness against adversarial attacks and noisy graph data. Fourth, we delve into explainability in GNNs, focusing on building trust in these models and providing insights into their decision-making processes. Lastly, we explore lifelong learning techniques for GNNs, enabling them to continuously learn and adapt to new graph data, addressing the challenge of non-stationary graph distributions and improving their long-term performance and applicability. We provide a comprehensive review of the state-of-the-art methods, theoretical foundations, and open challenges in these areas, aiming to inspire further research and development in GNNs.
